Fields.DialogueText: *KNOCK*
Enter!
Oh - hello. What can I do for you, Nubian?
Murhba, Qubtan! It is a matter of relatively little importance. Nevertheless, I thought it fitting to inform you.

Fields.MenuText: I don't have time for your personal pursuits, Nubian.
Certainly. What's on your mind?
It'll have to be quick. We're in difficult waters today.

Fields.DialogueText: I see. With respect, Qubtan, you would prefer to know about this now.
Sustainability, Qubtan!
Of course, Qubtan. I ask for only a moment.
No doubt you are aware how much of our crew's meals go uneaten.
I'm not. You'd think they wouldn't waste food in such a stressful environment.
If they have no use for their leftovers, I do. Have you seen the waste out there, on the bow?
Yesterday's dinner?
Left to rot for whatever is willing to finish it.
That would explain the gulls. They've been circling all day.
I doubt we'll have to rely on seagulls for food.
As do I. But should our usual options desert us, the sea will come to our aid.
Mmm... I am told these beasts taste of whatever they've eaten. Perhaps the crew will finish their dinner after all.
That's a... colorful idea.
This is a colorful world. And predictable. As the bait attracts the gulls, so the gulls attract the Morganas. Both to the slaughter, naturally!
You've got the right attitude, but I'm not sure we need to go looking for fights.
Do not fear, Qubtan. These ones are more afraid of us than we are of them.
@BATTLE
How curious, Qubtan...
What's wrong?
My trips to the galley are yielding less and less bait lately.

Fields.MenuText: Is that a problem?
Maybe the crew is eating better.
Perhaps this will persuade the gulls to leave.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps not, if my instincts about why are correct.
Maybe they are. I will have to ask them personally.
Cleaning them is a little more effort than it's worth, for the amount of food you get.
I honestly won't miss the gulls. They do grate on your nerves after the first... how long has it been?
Long enough for this experiment to have run its course. But if the crew is eating better, I consider it a success!
A shame, though... those gulls were uncommonly effective Morgana bait. Carrion birds for the carrion birds.
The crew will be happy to see them go.
Should the eagle be relieved at the snake's absence? We are hunters, you and I.
The less we see of those things, the better, in my book.
You misunderstand. I did not tell you not to fear the Morganas. I simply encourage us to practice killing them.
No shortage of that. Here come some now.
Mumtaz! I knew I smelled them coming.
@BATTLE
Ah! Qubtan, there you are. This itch has been bothering me all day, and I have finally found the source. Look here.
Rust on the guns? Might be time for some maintenance.
Not simply rust. Rust of the kind that takes days of neglect to build! Someone is neglecting their duty.

Fields.MenuText: It doesn't look that bad. It can probably wait until we're in port.
Don't hurt them. Just make sure they understand.
I'll get to the bottom of this.

Fields.DialogueText: Would you ride a horse with a limp, Qubtan?
La taqlaq. Do not worry. I will not cripple a fellow hunter.
You honor me, but this is a matter I would prefer to handle.
Maybe this merits a talk with the crew. It's one thing to neglect maintenance - quite another if the ship can complain.
"None can truly be said to believe until he wants for their brother what he wants for himself." The crew have a sister now. They can be made to understand.
I'm surprised you're taking this in stride. They say some other Belles wouldn't be nearly so patient.
One does not trap prey with vengeance or pettiness. Some of your human tribes pursue gazelles through simple endurance.
I don't follow.
Patience, Qubtan. The perpetrator must realize their mistake. I will think on how.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Qad jit fi, Qubtan?
Of course, Nubian. The door's unlocked.
Bringing your work home, I take it?

Fields.MenuText: My home is back on land. Here in my quarters, I'm at work.
Call it light reading.
Is this important?

Fields.DialogueText: You are dutiful. I respect that. Yet even a hunter must allow himself some rest.
That certainly doesn't look light.
A Belle can't catch up with her captain in idle hours?
I'm trying to stay informed about you Belles. Zurich can't update the dossiers fast enough.
Some of us can be a handful, can't we?
I've heard horror stories. They say there's a French Belle who makes her crew throw their least productive mate overboard each week.
Is it true?
Of course not. Every rumor starts somewhere, though...
She is a poor predator whose packmates fear her.
I'm honestly grateful you knock before entering. Some Belles come and go as they please. Their ship, their body, their space, and all that.
Ha! Their pride is misplaced - the crew is entitled to as much privacy as circumstances will allow. Ah, and now I remember what I meant to tell you.
What's that?
I have determined who has been neglecting their cleaning duties. All that remains is to elucidate their importance.
Nubian...
Never fear! Sometimes the alpha of the pack must discipline her subordinates. I only mean to–
Oh, dear. Another time, Qubtan. There are shaytans who fancy their chances!
Look. Can I trust you to be easy on the crew?
No. You may trust me to be fair.
@BATTLE
What was that at breakfast?
Surprise inspection, Qubtan! Almost all of them passed, too.
That's unusual, but not the first Belle inspection I've heard of. Nor the strangest.
I too have heard of Miss New Orleans and her... unprofessional streak.
I've already dressed down some of the crew over some bawdy songs to that effect.
Oh, let them have their fun! Better a bawdy song than a rusty gun.
You lingered on Seaman Reuss in particular. Our culprit?
Our culprit. I gave him a good talking-to afterward about proper maintenance.
Hopefully he got the message.
Well, remorse only goes so far. But I feel that he has a better understanding of the gravity of the situation.
What's that supposed to mean?
A little rust in one's socks speaks a language words cannot.
I thought you were above revenge.
I am. This was a test. Imagine all that grit in your socks, with nothing for it but to stand at attention and bear it. The little annoyances eat at you, and yet Reuss stood firm.

Fields.MenuText: How did you get the rust in his socks?
In your socks... do your guns correspond to a specific part of you?
Think that taught him a lesson?

Fields.DialogueText: A little stealth and patience will get you anywhere!
That is a question best left to human imagination.
If it does not, I will have underestimated him. But I have faith.
This was about more than just giving him pride in his work. That little endurance test gave him pride in himself. If I can bear that discomfort, why can't he?
More to the point, why should you?
"Make things easy for people and do not make them difficult." What could be easier than sharing a minor hardship in the name of preventing it?
The other Belles could learn a thing or two from you.
And I from them! But Morganas are approaching. Let us make this battle another lesson.
@BATTLE
Can you see them, Nubian?
Yes, though with this visibility I can only guess at their identity. I wonder...
I'm sure of it. Qubtan, take extra care with these fiends!
@BATTLE
I've had easier battles... but we made it. There was one that stood out. What was that Morgana?
Not what, but who. Or perhaps both. That was Starvation. She's made quite a name for herself in these waters.
I've read some of the reports. The one with the appetite.
That's one way of putting it. She used to publicly eat sailors who crossed her.
Used to?
Perhaps Zurich's dossiers need an update. They stepped up her coastal attacks after civilian boating died down.
So she's hungry.
If you like. It's simple predatory intimidation. Morganas do not need to eat... at least, I assume not. Most Belles do not need to, at any rate.

Fields.MenuText: That feast last night had me thinking otherwise.
Has she been... eating lately?
So you're saying we feed her some shells.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, let us just say that I hate to lose to you.
She makes her guardrails out of bone. Even if she hasn't, that's enough to unnerve anyone.
I share your enthusiasm, but we must temper it.
Now consider the jaguar.
You've lost me.
I will find you again. Starvation is like that great cat in her habits.
You're saying we should bait her with something.
Or someone.
If you can convince someone to fish in these waters, you're an even better con than you are a hunter.
We must be both, Qubtan! But I will fool a demon, not a human...
Ah, Qubtan! It is an honor to finally show you my quarters.
It's certainly... decorated. What is all this?
Call it my trophy room. I keep souvenirs of all our engagements.
Like this shell here?
A dud from Murder. Did you know Morganas fired duds?
You can't leave the ship. How do you get these?
Skill and luck. Sometimes both! My trophies may come right to me, in the case of the shell. Or I might notice something adrift on the waves, and only need to sail closer.
How come I'm only finding out about this now?
Until now I'd thought I could fill it out on my own. Yet some Morganas have proven elusive lately.
That's in their nature. They tend to be the ones setting the terms of engagement.
Exactly why I call you in here to help. You remember my little experiment with Seaman Reuss.
Of course.
Common experiences can work both ways. The more unique Morganas we defeat, the greater our reputation among their vile pack! All we need is to take more missions...

Fields.MenuText: I'm not going to change our patrols so you can collect things. We're on duty.
I'll recommend you for more tours and see if Zurich will agree.
There's only so much I can do where our missions are concerned.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm offering more than that, of course. I intend to show the world that there is nothing I, nothing we, cannot handle!
How can they not? The evidence of our prowess is all around you.
Just one more variable in our favor is all I ask. It is the only one I need.
As long as it's not just for your collection.
You humans are the apex predators, Qubtan, and we Belles are not far behind. Come, and help me teach these wayward Morganas of our power!
@BATTLE
May I come in, Nubian?
Ah! Finished. Yes, Qubtan!
Doing a little housekeeping?
Redecorating. Maintaining the habitat, as it were. I needed space for that piece of Miss Avarice.
What did we collect from these last Morganas?
Avarice is a rare specimen indeed! I was lucky enough to recover this from the ruin they left behind.
An anchor chain?
Her necklace! They may be drab and a touch scandalous, but you cannot deny that these beasts are creative.

Fields.MenuText: That looks like it might match your jewelry.
I've heard stories about Morgana pieces. Horror stories.
What if they come back for it?

Fields.DialogueText: The thought had crossed my mind, but I did not entertain it, thank heavens.
Bah! Ignore them. Give in to fear and the battle is already lost!
We get a bracelet to match.
I wanted to tell you that Zurich is pleased with your progress in the Atlantic. They're willing to send us after new Morganas as they appear.
Mumtaz! Exactly as I had hoped. Oh, move that mannequin... there, won't you?
Hmm? Oh, of course.
Fi 'ahsan alahwal... Perfect! Soon, there will be many more trophies like this one.
"Be in this world as if you were a stranger..."
"... or a traveller on the road." I am familiar with the Prophet's words, peace be upon him. I can't take these with me, I know. They serve as a reminder to the crew and to myself.
Your victories aren't reminder enough?
Even I doubt myself sometimes. There are memories in each of these relics that encourage me not to.
Like this armor plating from the Despair?
Ah, yes. That one reminds me that even Morganas will blush when they are exposed!
You've seen a Morgana blush?
Oh, for a camera to demonstrate with this one!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
*ALARM*
Hold course...
Let's not let them get away.
@BATTLE
Excuse me. As you were. Pardon me... Nubian?
Ah, Qubtan, as-salaam 'alaykum!
Just a moment... Oh! Why, you... Ha! Try again, Buechner!
What's all this, then?
A challenge of strength and agility, Qubtan! Double rations to the first man who can throw me out of this ring.
Should I be concerned?
Only if they succeed.
Must you do this at this hour?
On such a busy day as this has been? When else are we to practice?
Are you willing to fight for that right?
My, my, Qubtan! Was that a challenge?

Fields.MenuText: If you're willing to take it.
For - wait, you mean - no, I'm not suggesting...
Don't even bother. You know it wouldn't be appropriate.

Fields.DialogueText: All too eager, Qubtan!
Oh, I rather think you are...
Not appropriate to fight your Belle? Or not appropriate to lose?
Fine. Don't hold back.
I never do.
Whoa!
And that's a ring out. Best of three, Qubtan? Or may I keep this hour to train in?
Yes.
Yes, what?
Yes, all of the above. Another round.
Today's battle wasn't enough for you? I quite agree!
Oh, there you are, Nubian. I was beginning to wonder where you'd gone.
Just thinking, Qubtan. I took some time after prayers to plan our ambush on today's prey.
I'm still trying to make sense of it all.
That Morganas would eat people? As I said, Qubtan, she is only trying to scare you.
No, just... Belles praying. I don't really know how that comes about.
It does seem odd, doesn't it? I'm a destroyer, aren't I? I know who created me.
That's more or less what I thought.
True enough. Yet when you look at me, do you see a destroyer?
Well... yes.
A fair answer, but I know you see more than that. I think and feel as you do, I fight alongside you. Occasionally I throw you over my shoulder for the crew's amusement.
My shoulder still aches from that bout...
Mankind may have created my body, just as your parents created yours, Qubtan. But they did not create my soul. They did not create a thing of passions, of desires, of questions.
But why here? Why now? Why a warship?
When I see them, I will be sure to ask. For now, there are demons that seek to undo God's work. It's the least I can do to help preserve it.

Fields.MenuText: I hadn't thought of the Morganas that way.

Fields.DialogueText: Many Belles do not think this way. But "whoever is deprived of kindness is deprived of all good." No matter what you believe in, we can all agree on that.
Deprived of kindness... almost makes you pity the Morganas, doesn't it?
Insha'Allah, though that may be the hardest thing he asks of me.
@BATTLE
Prepare yourself, Qubtan. They approach us even now...

Fields.MenuText: Morganas must have a diabolical origin.

Fields.DialogueText: I urge you to consider it, but do not feel ignorant, Qubtan.
I believe that is possible, and some other Belles also think this.
Look there! Have you ever seen her like before?
Thinking of a trophy already?
Not only of that...
@BATTLE
Another successful hunt! My journal will sing of this day.
Find anything good on her?
A scrap of her colors. Nothing too out of the ordinary. Perhaps it will look good above the door.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if Zurich know they're helping you decorate.
What do you consider "out of the ordinary"?
Aren't Morgana artifacts dangerous?

Fields.DialogueText: If they do, they also know that we are steadily driving the demons from the coasts.
One of these days I will find a manifest... perhaps even a black box! Just imagine...
There is no such thing as curses, Qubtan, ghost ships notwithstanding.
But we still have yet to face our real quarry...
Starvation?
Alas, she is the one that got away. The one I have not wrested a keepsake from.
Wouldn't it be convenient if she were also the one closest to home port?
I hesitate to play with civilian lives... but she must be getting arrogant. It is only a matter of time before we see her again.
I thought you'd suggest luring her somehow.
Give me a few more battles to become impatient.
Writing a letter?
Aye, Qubtan! The time has come for me to compare notes with my sisters.
Are they hunters like you?
Many of them, yes. I maintain the high kill count for now, but Ashanti and Gurkha were right on my heels last I checked.
I don't know if I'd call it a kill count. We haven't actually been able to destroy any Morganas yet.
It is the unfortunate nature of this hunt. Imagine if we could run one of these demons aground...
Nubian? You're gripping that pen a little tightly.
Do not mind me. Our patience will surely be rewarded... in time.
If you say so.
Do you know I have a space over my bed specifically reserved for one of their heads!? But they run, and they run, and they run... I could just burn to the waterline, thinking about it!

Fields.MenuText: I thought you were the patient one around here.
Please don't.
The war's barely begun. One of these days we'll catch a Morgana and keep her.

Fields.DialogueText: Fighting the Morganas is a lesser jihad, Qubtan. Patience in the face of elusiveness is the greater.
God has not seen fit to do that to me, nor will he.
We should have done so ten times over!
Do forgive me, but it is simply an impossible puzzle. What keeps us from the coup de grace? It is like watching a shattered snake crawl its way to safety!
According to Zurich, we might face Calamity today.
I can always count on a little perspective from you, can't I?
Glad to help. You've got ink all the way up to the elbow, by the way.
Insult to injury!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Nubian, take the spyglass. This is your kill.
Then allow me to use my rifle's sights. It will get me in the mood.
Well?
It's her. See there, on the prow?
I've seen bones on a Morgana before.
My eyes are sharper than yours. The scoring on the bones... teeth, I'm sure of it.
Starvation?
Starvation.
And without even needing to bait her.
Do not be too quick to celebrate, Qubtan. This is a trap.

Fields.MenuText: So you're saying we shoot first.
I'll recommend a withdrawal until we know what we're up against.
You mean we're surrounded?

Fields.DialogueText: La, you must never make the first move!
Slow and steady, Qubtan. Others of her kind may be on the move.
Only if we allow it.
What do you think you'll take from her?
I will know when she gives it to me.
Wait... on our starboard! Look!
May she be sewn up alive in the belly of a dead camel! A diversion...
@BATTLE
Redecorating?
Calming down.
You never did tell me what you took from Starvation.
La, for I did not think it important. It's over there on that shelf.
Is that a skull from Starvation's prow?
Macabre, isn't it? It was one of hers... and now it is also mine.
That used to belong to someone, you know.
Used to. Its owner has no more need for it.

Fields.MenuText: Even so, you can't be comfortable just having it there.
No, I suppose not.
I'll bet Starvation said the same thing.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a victory over our most savage enemy, Qubtan. I will learn.
I can't help but wonder whose this was. What must they have seen?
Starvation kept this to intimidate. I keep it to reassure.
I'll come back later, if that's what you want.
The Morganas desire otherwise. We should go to the bridge.
@BATTLE
I thought that would never end.
They fight all the fiercer for being cornered. We've got them on the run, Qubtan, make no mistake. As the battles grow difficult, our ultimate victory draws nearer.
No trophies today?
Perhaps another time... I find our foes have put me off the practice for now.
Nubian, if there's anything I can do...
Even the bloodiest carnivore kills for survival, Qubtan. What possesses these things to kill your people? Sport? Hate? Lions do not hate gazelles.
I'm sorry if I offended you earlier.
"A strong person is not the person who throws his adversaries to the ground. A strong person is the person who contains himself when he is angry." I keep that hadith close to my heart.
You're one of the stronger people I've met.
And you, Qubtan, for all the horror we face. I am reminded of another hadith.
Which one?
"If someone does not show mercy to people, God will not show mercy to him."
Alllaenat, alllaenat, alllaenat... A hundred curses... There! I think that's the worst of it!
Repairs?
Hello there, Qubtan! Just patching up a leak in this feedwater tank. What brings you down here?
One of the engineers told me you chased him out with a wrench.
He kept insisting he knew what was causing my headaches, but I knew he was full of himself. I must report this when we put into port for more extensive refits.
Even with malfunctions, you always seem to be at the top of your game.
We Royal Navy types pride ourselves on it, Qubtan! Especially Tribals. We've got a way of bouncing back and sticking together. I am not the first Nubian, you know.
No?
My... you might call her my grandmother or my great-aunt. At any rate, there was a Nubian during the Great War. She lost her bow at Dover Strait in ‘16, but did that stop her?
She kept sailing without a bow?
No, but luckily the old Zulu lost her stern at Dunkirk two weeks later. They sewed the two together and set them afloat once more, with a colorful rechristening. Care to guess her new name?

Fields.MenuText: I couldn't possibly.
The... Nulu?
Nubian, I don't have time for this.

Fields.DialogueText: Certainly not if you give up so quickly!
Wrong... but you are on the right track!
I ask only for another moment.
What was she called?
Zubian!
That's... accurate.
It is always better to repair than to replace, I think. That is why you find me down here.
Can you at least apologize to the engineer in question?
I will show him the error of his ways, and then he may work where I work. A good apology includes a lesson for all involved.
You may need to hold off for now. It sounds like we've got trouble. How's it look?
Well... if the waters are not too rough and we do not move too quickly... challenging. Just the way I like it.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Look at the sky! Isn't it beautiful today?
Slate gray, threatening rain. It's beautiful, all right.
Look beyond the weather, Qubtan. We sail with the wind into the perfect conditions to capture our prey!
Asphyxiation doesn't like storms?
Not if we damage her enough. We shall set this one adrift and at the mercy of God himself!

Fields.MenuText: Some days I wish God would just take care of them.
Maybe this will be the one we manage to sink.
They have a way of coming back from that kind of thing.

Fields.DialogueText: Eventually God may, but reserves that mercy for our final day.
Then we will drown her a fourth time!
Let them. I have a way of beating them back!
I just hope you're right about the conditions.
Do not simply hope, Qubtan. Act!
@BATTLE
The time for that is now. Enemy contact, Nubian. Battle stations!
Here are the dispatches from London you wanted.
Shukran! My gratitude, Qubtan. I've been meaning to do this for ages.
You've been at this all day. What's the project?
You could call it a shopping list, Qubtan. I'm trying to trace the movements of the Morganas in the North Atlantic, old and new.
What are you learning?
Wonderful things! I feared these alshayatin would vex me further, but there are patterns to many of their raids.
Good work, Nubian. This could help us immensely if we knew what to expect where.
Na'am... which leaves the question of when. I can only rely so much on instinct, and I was never much for statistics. Which of my sisters was good at that, I wonder...?

Fields.MenuText: Don't forget the human element. I'm sure our codebreakers could help.
We'll have to ask around. One step closer to saving the coasts.
Assuming the Morganas don't change the plans.

Fields.DialogueText: I have heard of Scotland Yard's efforts to decipher their awful broadcasts. The rumors are ugly.
It does not matter who discovers these creatures' patterns. I want to be there to break them.
Even the unpredictable can be made predictable, if you are familiar with the prey. That is where theory ends and practice begins.
So whom do your instincts say we'll be fighting next?
The science is inexact, but we should be in Disease's stomping grounds. I wager we'll find her–
*BOOM*
And so we have.
@BATTLE
Qubtan, have you noticed anything... concerning about our hunts of late?
Other than that they're for ghost ships?
No, that comes with being the world's foremost hunters. I cannot help but notice that we are seeing some familiar faces.
Why wouldn't we? We've known for a while that Morganas can repair themselves somehow.
I've been tracking their movements for weeks now, Qubtan. This isn't right. Some of them have veered hundreds of miles off course to engage us! But why?

Fields.MenuText: I thought they might be unpredictable.
Are you sure your measurements are right?
Isn't it more important that we be prepared for anything?

Fields.DialogueText: Even so, Qubtan, that doesn't explain the phenomenon.
Triple-checked every evening. I'm sure.
We already are, Qubtan, rest assured. But what could be preparing for us?
Think about it. We asked Zurich to send us after new Morganas.
Trophy rooms don't build themselves.
Yes, well, apart from that. Why do we keep seeing the same ones?
Apart from Starvation.
The last time we saw her was...
When you took that bone from her.
I will have to think on this some more, Qubtan. Are we almost caught up to Fire?
For the third time this tour.
Curse her entire class... but I am ready, Qubtan!
@BATTLE
Qubtan, I want to try something dangerous.
Oh, no.
Hear me out. Look at my notes. One list is Morganas from whom I have taken a trophy. Any piece of them at all.
I'm with you so far. You hadn't counted coup with some of them after Starvation.
I thank God for my bout of squeamishness. The other list is Morganas with whom we have had repeated encounters.
The trophies have something to do with that?
They must! Without the non-trophy Morganas to control for this, I would never have seen it.

Fields.MenuText: It's got to be a coincidence. We've been patrolling the same basic area.
Why should that worry us? We can deal with anything that comes our way.
You're saying that they're... attracted somehow?

Fields.DialogueText: Qubtan, all of the deviations in the Morganas' routes occur no more than a week after our first encounter with them. Trust me when I say I have tracked them straight to us!
Look again. They are striking within weeks of each other, and their attacks are getting more frequent. What happens when they all appear at once?
It must be the case. Whatever my trophies are doing, it's bringing the Morganas right to our position like clockwork.
That's why I want this next patrol to be completely silent. No radio, no mail, nothing. I have to prove that the Morganas have some kind of remote awareness!
You don't have to be the one to do it. This has to go through proper channels before-
Before what? Before some beachcomber finds a shell washed up on shore and brings Starvation straight to his fishing village?
We're going over this again once we're out of hot water. We're about to engage-
Cowardice?
How did you know?
Sometimes I hate when I am right.
@BATTLE
It's a quiet day today.
No contact with port, as you requested. This isn't a good idea.
Neither is continuing to sail when the seas are brimming with demons. Yet here we are.
There's a lot of guesswork in what we're doing. Assuming the Morganas are drawn to your trophies, how do we know they'll coordinate? And what if we need help?
I've been over the maps and the notes dawn to dusk. Several will converge near our coordinates. That we can deal with.
If we extrapolate some of Zurich's planned patrols... it does not look good for us.

Fields.MenuText: So what? We keep going out there until we're overwhelmed?
Then why us out here?
There's a simple solution I'm sure you've considered. Stop taking trophies.

Fields.DialogueText: Only if we do not vary our hunting behavior.
Because we are the ones responsible.
That was the first thing that occurred to me. But it is not as simple as that.
You're talking in riddles, Nubian. This isn't like you.
There, port side.
The usual suspects.
Luckily, evolution is a slow process.
@BATTLE
Brace yourself, Qubtan. We're on the trail of Starvation.
I know. Zurich sent me more intelligence on her. It's not a pleasant read.
When you no longer need to invent stories about your enemy, you face a truly terrible beast.
Slaughter is one thing, but cannibalism? Where's the sense in that? What's the point?
The Morganas are fear. They wield it like any other weapon. Or Starvation may simply enjoy it.
God as my witness, I cannot decide what is worse.
Well, the job is the job. She was closest to our planned patrol.
No, actually, she was not.
What's that?
I misled you about the nature of my decisions, Qubtan. Proximity alone would have us fighting different Morganas. Another of my sisters is taking care of them.
Then why would we be fighting Starvation?
Penance.

Fields.MenuText: Nubian, we're at war! You can't make that call.

Fields.DialogueText: I can and I will! Some other Morganas are approaching, and they are too close for argument, Qubtan. I will tell you in time.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Not exactly by the book, but I'm willing to let you do whatever you think you must.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate that, Qubtan. I will tell you more when I can, but for now the Morganas draw near.
There she is, Qubtan. Starvation, and her group. Is the radio room ready?
It'll be all clear once we confirm their retreat. I need to know what you're doing with it. You can't just be saying goodbye.
This is something I must speak to her about first. It is between her and me.
If you say so.
@BATTLE
What's that you've got there?
Another bone, Qubtan. I wanted to explain it to you... here, in my trophy room.

Fields.MenuText: I'm listening.
You're flirting with mutiny, Nubian.
I don't think I'll ever understand your hobbies.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Qubtan. This is not the easiest thing to tell you.
I have a responsibility to myself as much as to the fleet.
At least attempt to.
Look at the trophies, Qubtan. The flags, the armor, the bones... what do they have in common?
They're all Morgana artifacts, of course.
Before they were Morgana, they were human. We know these beasts repair themselves. We know they cannibalize your ships, your people.
You may think it ludicrous, Qubtan, but these trophies are not simply mine to take. One day I must return them to their rightful owners.
And here I thought you were doing it out of pride. I wouldn't have blamed you.
There is a time and a place for pride. One day I will have to renounce it. Think of it as the next great hunt... for peace, instead of for war.
Is that what you told Starvation?
I told her we would strike her down wherever she reared her head. I told her we would strip her of everything she'd stolen. Undo everything she'd done. Love everything she'd hated.
And what did she say?
She laughed. I suppose I was foolish to expect otherwise.
You were hopeful. Nothing wrong with that.
Hope, but keep your gun loaded.
You're packing?
I'm packing.
You can't leave. This ship is... well, you.
Just my trophies. The Morganas have already started to deviate from my calculations.
We're not attracting them anymore?
We never truly did. They simply knew where to find us.
That doesn't make sense. Why would they give up an advantage like that?
There is little military utility in focusing all your strength on a single point in the opponent's defense. Especially if that point refuses to fear you.
So this was about you?
It's about all of us, Qubtan. We did not simply fight the Morganas. We humiliated them, and we continue to do so. I could not ask for a better pack to hunt with.
Then it's back to business as usual.
Na'am. The Morganas will find another chink in our armor and try that, and they will fail.
This enemy adapts. They learn your weaknesses, both on the battlefield and in your heart. The lesser jihad and the greater. It is taxing... and yet it is thrilling.

Fields.MenuText: They may learn, but you learn more quickly.
There's nothing thrilling about fighting for your life.
The trophies don't hurt either.

Fields.DialogueText: Nature is cruel, and we must be crueler.
Not if you lose.
Except when they do.
I'm sorry I doubted you.
No, Qubtan, I am sorry I was not more honest with you. We will move these trophies somewhere inland. Switzerland ought to have some secure vaults for them.
It looks like there are Morganas that want in on it.
They will have it!
@BATTLE
You look hard at work, Nubian.
Just taking inventory before we offload these trophies. Some are easier than others.
You can make out some of the pennant numbers on the armor and fabric.
Among other things. Most of these will be easy to repatriate. Others less so.
Like the Starvation artifacts.
There is only so much we can do with bones.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure Starvation has decorating tips.
I'll be glad to be rid of them.
Why don't we bury them at sea and have done with it?

Fields.DialogueText: Mudhik. Noted and politely disregarded.
Feel free, Qubtan, though you are not the one who took them.
If it comes to that, we will, but I would prefer to return them to where they belong.
You don't have to do any of this, you know. Isn't it enough to make the world safe?
Perhaps it is, but I cannot accept that. "Be in the world as if you were a stranger or a traveller on the road." If a stranger found your belongings, would you not want them returned?
I wouldn't mind them being trophies for a particularly skilled hunter.
Hold on to that sense of humor, Qubtan. These Morganas may set me in search of it again.
@BATTLE
Command's mulling a transfer from the North Atlantic, Nubian.
To where?
They haven't decided. The eastern Mediterranean and the Caribbean always need hands, but the Indian Ocean's been hot lately as well.
I have no preference. The hunt will take us where it takes us. Ours is the task to learn the lay of the land!
Even if it means fighting Morganas in the Arctic?
Especially if it means fighting Morganas in the Arctic! I have always wanted to see the edges of this world.
You never know what you might find.
That is why we keep our guns loaded and our crew fed. Will you dine with me tonight, Qubtan?

Fields.MenuText: Dinner? Of course! Is there any... special reason?
Dinner sounds great, Nubian.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, nothing too important - just something I'd like to discuss.
Good, I have a matter to discuss with you.
Catching seagulls again?
That little experiment need not be repeated. But I thought the crew could use a little diversity. What would they say if I cooked once in a while?
I suspect they'd say yes. Any particular reason?
Just another means of giving back to my fellow hunters. There's more to putting a fire in their belly than the occasional boxing match!
Good thought, Nubian. I look forward to the completed menu.
